mn152:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gajaṅgalāyaṃ viharati suveḷuvane.
mn152:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kajaṅgalā in a bamboo grove.
mn152:1.2.comm: The names here are spelled gajaṅgalā and suveḷuvana, but I keep consistency with AN 10.28, where a nun residing at this town gives a penetrative discourse to the townsfolk. In the Vinaya it is mentioned as the easternmost point of the “middle country”, just beyond which lay Mahāsāla (Kd 5:13.12.2). The Milindapañha says it was a brahmin village on the slopes of the Himalayas where its main protagonist, the monk Nāgasena, was born (Mil 2:22.3). Assuming both these are the same place, we might look somewhere near Darjeeling for this town. In any case, it represents the furthest east that the Buddha taught. It is sometimes identified with 羯蠅揭羅 mentioned by Xuang Zang, but that has been located near Agra south of Sāvatthī.

mn152:2.1.pli: Atha kho uttaro māṇavo pārāsiviyantevāsī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn152:2.1.eng: Then the student Uttara, a pupil of the brahmin Pārāsariya, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
mn152:2.1.comm: A brahmin teacher named Pārāsariya (also spelled Pārāpariya or Pārāsiviya) features in Ja 222 and Ja 353 as one who warns that doing evil will lead to regret. The three similarly-named monks in the Theragāthā (Thag 1.116, Thag 16.2, Thag 16.10) share the same clan name (Sanskrit Pārāśarya). These are descendants of the great sage Parāśara Śāktya, who is mentioned in Rig Veda 7.1.18 alongside Śatayātu, Vasiṣṭha; his prayers to Agni are recorded at Rig Veda 1.65–73, and to Soma at 9.97.31–44.

mn152:2.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho uttaraṃ māṇavaṃ pārāsiviyantevāsiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
mn152:2.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

mn152:2.3.eng: “Uttara, does Pārāsariya teach his disciples the development of the faculties?”

mn152:2.4.pli: “Deseti, bho gotama, pārāsiviyo brāhmaṇo sāvakānaṃ indriyabhāvanan”ti.

mn152:2.5.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, uttara, deseti pārāsiviyo brāhmaṇo sāvakānaṃ indriyabhāvanan”ti?

mn152:2.6.pli: “Idha, bho gotama, cakkhunā rūpaṃ na passati, sotena saddaṃ na suṇāti—
mn152:2.6.eng: “Worthy Gotama, it’s when the eye sees no sight and the ear hears no sound.
mn152:2.6.comm: This is perhaps a distorted reference to certain Upaniṣadic teachings that speak of the undifferentiated state of divinity that contains the potential for the faculties of seeing, etc. See DN 29:16.13 and note there. Perhaps, too, it refers to the notion that in deep sleep the senses are withdrawn into the “space of the heart” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.17).

mn152:2.7.pli: evaṃ kho, bho gotama, deseti pārāsiviyo brāhmaṇo sāvakānaṃ indriyabhāvanan”ti.
mn152:2.7.eng: That’s how Pārāsariya teaches his disciples the development of the faculties.”

mn152:2.8.pli: “Evaṃ sante kho, uttara, andho bhāvitindriyo bhavissati, badhiro bhāvitindriyo bhavissati;
mn152:2.8.eng: “In that case, Uttara, a blind person and a deaf person will have developed faculties

mn152:2.10.pli: Andho hi, uttara, cakkhunā rūpaṃ na passati, badhiro sotena saddaṃ na suṇātī”ti.
mn152:2.10.eng: For a blind person sees no sight with the eye and a deaf person hears no sound with the ear.”
mn152:2.10.comm: This teaching is not about deep meditation, where the senses can be in a state of abeyance, but about how we relate to the experience of the senses.

mn152:2.11.pli: Evaṃ vutte, uttaro māṇavo pārāsiviyantevāsī tuṇhībhūto maṅkubhūto pattakkhandho adhomukho pajjhāyanto appaṭibhāno nisīdi.
mn152:2.11.eng: When he said this, Uttara sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.

mn152:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā uttaraṃ māṇavaṃ pārāsiviyantevāsiṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ maṅkubhūtaṃ pattakkhandhaṃ adhomukhaṃ pajjhāyantaṃ appaṭibhānaṃ viditvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
mn152:3.1.eng: Knowing this, the Buddha addressed Venerable Ānanda,

mn152:3.2.pli: “aññathā kho, ānanda, deseti pārāsiviyo brāhmaṇo sāvakānaṃ indriyabhāvanaṃ, aññathā ca panānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā hotī”ti.
mn152:3.2.eng: “Ānanda, the development of the faculties taught by Pārāsariya is quite different from the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One.”

mn152:3.3.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One.

mn152:3.4.pli: yaṃ bhagavā ariyassa vinaye anuttaraṃ indriyabhāvanaṃ deseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
mn152:3.4.eng: Let the Buddha teach the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

mn152:3.5.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn152:3.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

mn152:4.1.eng: “And how, Ānanda, is there the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One?

mn152:4.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:4.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, in them arises what is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable.

mn152:4.4.pli: ‘uppannaṃ kho me idaṃ manāpaṃ, uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ, uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:4.4.eng: ‘What is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable have arisen in me.

mn152:4.5.eng: That’s conditioned, crude, and dependently originated.

mn152:4.6.eng: But this is peaceful and sublime, namely

mn152:4.8.pli: Tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati;
mn152:4.8.eng: Then the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease,

mn152:4.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, cakkhumā puriso ummīletvā vā nimīleyya, nimīletvā vā ummīleyya;
mn152:4.10.eng: It’s like how a person with clear eyes might open their eyes then shut them; or might shut their eyes then open them.
mn152:4.10.comm: The Buddha gives a series of similes, each one appropriate to the specific sense.

mn152:4.11.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
mn152:4.11.eng: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

mn152:4.12.pli: ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu.
mn152:4.12.eng: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding sights known by the eye.
mn152:4.12.comm: Bearing in mind that the word for “faculty”, indriya, has the sense of “potential”, this phrase emphasizes that the “restraint” of the senses is also the way to “develop” them to their fullest.

mn152:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno sotena saddaṃ sutvā uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:5.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears a sound with their ears, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:5.3.pli: ‘uppannaṃ kho me idaṃ manāpaṃ, uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ, uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:5.3.eng: ‘What is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable have arisen in me.

mn152:5.4.eng: That’s conditioned, crude, and dependently originated.

mn152:5.5.eng: But this is peaceful and sublime, namely

mn152:5.7.pli: Tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati;
mn152:5.7.eng: Then the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease,

mn152:5.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, balavā puriso appakasireneva accharaṃ pahareyya;
mn152:5.9.eng: It’s like how a strong person can effortlessly snap their fingers.

mn152:5.10.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
mn152:5.10.eng: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

mn152:5.11.pli: ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā sotaviññeyyesu saddesu.
mn152:5.11.eng: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding sounds known by the ear.

mn152:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno ghānena gandhaṃ ghāyitvā uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:6.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant smells an odor with their nose, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:6.3.pli: ‘uppannaṃ kho me idaṃ manāpaṃ, uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ, uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:6.3.eng: ‘What is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable have arisen in me.

mn152:6.4.eng: That’s conditioned, crude, and dependently originated.

mn152:6.5.eng: But this is peaceful and sublime, namely

mn152:6.7.pli: Tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati;
mn152:6.7.eng: Then the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease,

mn152:6.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, īsakampoṇe padumapalāse udakaphusitāni pavattanti, na saṇṭhanti;
mn152:6.9.eng: It’s like how a drop of water would roll off a gently sloping lotus leaf, and would not stay there.

mn152:6.10.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
mn152:6.10.eng: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

mn152:6.11.pli: ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā ghānaviññeyyesu gandhesu.
mn152:6.11.eng: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding smells known by the nose.

mn152:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:7.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant tastes a flavor with their tongue, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:7.3.pli: ‘uppannaṃ kho me idaṃ manāpaṃ, uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ, uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:7.3.eng: ‘What is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable have arisen in me.

mn152:7.4.eng: That’s conditioned, crude, and dependently originated.

mn152:7.5.eng: But this is peaceful and sublime, namely

mn152:7.7.pli: Tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati;
mn152:7.7.eng: Then the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease,

mn152:7.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, balavā puriso jivhagge kheḷapiṇḍaṃ saṃyūhitvā appakasirena vameyya;
mn152:7.9.eng: It’s like how a strong person who’s formed a glob of spit on the tip of their tongue could easily spit it out.

mn152:7.10.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
mn152:7.10.eng: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

mn152:7.11.pli: ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu.
mn152:7.11.eng: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding tastes known by the tongue.

mn152:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusitvā uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:8.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant feels a touch with their body, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:8.3.pli: ‘uppannaṃ kho me idaṃ manāpaṃ, uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ, uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:8.3.eng: ‘What is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable have arisen in me.

mn152:8.4.eng: That’s conditioned, crude, and dependently originated.

mn152:8.5.eng: But this is peaceful and sublime, namely

mn152:8.7.pli: Tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati;
mn152:8.7.eng: Then the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease,

mn152:8.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya;
mn152:8.9.eng: It’s like how a strong person can extend or contract their arm.

mn152:8.10.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
mn152:8.10.eng: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

mn152:8.11.pli: ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā kāyaviññeyyesu phoṭṭhabbesu.
mn152:8.11.eng: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding touches known by the body.

mn152:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno manasā dhammaṃ viññāya uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:9.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant knows a thought with their mind, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:9.3.pli: ‘uppannaṃ kho me idaṃ manāpaṃ, uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ, uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:9.3.eng: ‘What is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable have arisen in me.

mn152:9.4.eng: That’s conditioned, crude, and dependently originated.

mn152:9.5.eng: But this is peaceful and sublime, namely

mn152:9.7.pli: Tassa taṃ uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati;
mn152:9.7.eng: Then the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease,

mn152:9.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, balavā puriso divasaṃsantatte ayokaṭāhe dve vā tīṇi vā udakaphusitāni nipāteyya.
mn152:9.9.eng: It’s like how a strong person could let two or three drops of water fall onto an iron cauldron that had been heated all day.

mn152:9.10.pli: Dandho, ānanda, udakaphusitānaṃ nipāto, atha kho naṃ khippameva parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya;
mn152:9.10.eng: The drops would be slow to fall, but they’d quickly dry up and evaporate.

mn152:9.11.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, yassa kassaci evaṃsīghaṃ evaṃtuvaṭaṃ evaṃappakasirena uppannaṃ manāpaṃ uppannaṃ amanāpaṃ uppannaṃ manāpāmanāpaṃ nirujjhati, upekkhā saṇṭhāti—
mn152:9.11.eng: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.

mn152:9.12.pli: ayaṃ vuccatānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā manoviññeyyesu dhammesu.
mn152:9.12.eng: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding ideas known by the mind.

mn152:9.13.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā hoti.
mn152:9.13.eng: That’s how there is the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One.

mn152:10.1.eng: And how are they a practicing trainee?
mn152:10.1.comm: This is at least a stream-enterer; they still react to sense experiences that are agreeable or disagreeable, but they understand that they lead to suffering and train themselves to be freed..

mn152:10.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:10.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:10.3.pli: So tena uppannena manāpena uppannena amanāpena uppannena manāpāmanāpena aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati.
mn152:10.3.eng: They are horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.

mn152:10.4.eng: When they hear a sound with their ears …

mn152:10.5.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

mn152:10.6.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

mn152:10.7.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

mn152:10.8.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:10.8.eng: When they know a thought with their mind, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:10.9.pli: So tena uppannena manāpena uppannena amanāpena uppannena manāpāmanāpena aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati.
mn152:10.9.eng: They are horrified, repelled, and disgusted by that.

mn152:10.10.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, sekho hoti pāṭipado.
mn152:10.10.eng: That’s how they are a practicing trainee.

mn152:11-15.1.eng: And how are they a noble one with developed faculties?
mn152:11-15.1.comm: This is the arahant. They still experience sense stimulation as pleasant, etc., but without reacting.

mn152:11-15.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:11-15.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:11-15.3.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
mn152:11-15.3.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.
mn152:11-15.3.comm: Here this ability is fully mastered. It is taught to those in training as a practice at AN 5.144.

mn152:11-15.4.pli: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
mn152:11-15.4.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:11-15.5.pli: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle ca appaṭikūle ca appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
mn152:11-15.5.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:11-15.6.pli: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle ca paṭikūle ca paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
mn152:11-15.6.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive and the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:11-15.7.pli: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūlañca appaṭikūlañca tadubhayaṃ abhinivajjetvā upekkhako vihareyyaṃ sato sampajāno’ti, upekkhako tattha viharati sato sampajāno.
mn152:11-15.7.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, shunning both the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno sotena saddaṃ sutvā …pe…
mn152:16.1.eng: When they hear a sound with their ear …

mn152:16.2.eng: When they smell an odor with their nose …

mn152:16.3.eng: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …

mn152:16.4.eng: When they feel a touch with their body …

mn152:16.5.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya uppajjati manāpaṃ, uppajjati amanāpaṃ, uppajjati manāpāmanāpaṃ.
mn152:16.5.eng: When they know a thought with their mind, the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable arise in them.

mn152:16.6.pli: So sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
mn152:16.6.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:16.7.pli: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
mn152:16.7.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:16.8.pli: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle ca appaṭikūle ca appaṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, appaṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
mn152:16.8.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:16.9.pli: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘appaṭikūle ca paṭikūle ca paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
mn152:16.9.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive and the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:16.10.pli: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūlañca appaṭikūlañca tadubhayampi abhinivajjetvā upekkhako vihareyyaṃ sato sampajāno’ti, upekkhako tattha viharati sato sampajāno.
mn152:16.10.eng: If they wish: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, shunning both the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.

mn152:16.11.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, ariyo hoti bhāvitindriyo.
mn152:16.11.eng: That’s how they are a noble one with developed faculties.

mn152:17.1.pli: Iti kho, ānanda, desitā mayā ariyassa vinaye anuttarā indriyabhāvanā, desito sekho pāṭipado, desito ariyo bhāvitindriyo.
mn152:17.1.eng: So, Ānanda, I have taught the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One, I have taught the practicing trainee, and I have taught the noble one with developed faculties.

mn152:18.1.pli: Yaṃ kho, ānanda, satthārā karaṇīyaṃ sāvakānaṃ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṃ upādāya, kataṃ vo taṃ mayā.
mn152:18.1.eng: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.

mn152:18.2.pli: Etāni, ānanda, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni, jhāyathānanda, mā pamādattha, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṃ vo amhākaṃ anusāsanī”ti.
mn152:18.2.eng: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
mn152:18.2.comm: The Majjhima Nikāya ends with the Buddha encouraging the archetypal student of the suttas, Ānanda, to develop meditation.

mn152:18.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn152:18.4.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn152:18.4.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
